Ricardo Lagos was forced into exile in 1973 following a military coup by General Augusto Pinochet, where he remained until the late 1970s.
Ricardo Lagos was forced into exile in 1973 following a military coup by General Augusto Pinochet, where he remained until the late 1970s.
His memorable intervention on live television in 1988, challenging General Pinochet’s attempt to extend his rule by nationwide plebiscite, was seen as a pivotal moment in Chile’s transition.

He later served as Minister for Education, and Minister for Public Works in the mid-1990s under Presidents Patricio Aylwin and Eduardo Frei, and in 2000, he was elected President of Chile, twelve years after helping to lead his country back to democracy after Pinochet’s dictatorship.

He later served as Minister for Education, and Minister for Public Works in the mid-1990s under Presidents Patricio Aylwin and Eduardo Frei, and in 2000, he was elected President of Chile, twelve years after helping to lead his country back to democracy after Pinochet’s dictatorship.

label.label: Freedom House Award
label.reasoning: Recognition from a prominent international organization for contributions to freedom and democracy.

supporting_quotes: Freedom House’s 2014 Freedom in the World report categorized Chile as “free” with an overall freedom rating of one, with one being the freest and seven being the least.
events.notes: This event represents a one-time recognition by Freedom House, classifying Chile as 'free' in their report.

quotes: In 1980, the Pinochet regime promulgated a new constitution.
It included a provision calling a referendum in 1988, allowing voters a yes or no vote on whether to prolong Pinochet’s tenure as president.
In 1989, Chilean democracy was fully restored by a democratic election to choose a new president, the first free election in nearly twenty years.
Since the return to democracy, Chile has implemented significant economic and political reforms, including a free trade agreement with the United States.
Freedom House’s 2014 Freedom in the World report categorized Chile as “free” with an overall freedom rating of one, with one being the freest and seven being the least.

label.label: Honorary Degree from Harvard University
label.reasoning: Prestigious honorary degree from one of the world's leading universities, signifying significant academic or professional achievements.

supporting_quotes: On 24 May 2018, he was awarded the Doctor of Laws degree by Harvard University.
events.notes: One-time honorary degree award.

quotes: On 14 January 2017, Lagos accepted the Party for Democracy's nomination to run for president in 2017.
In early 2007, Lagos became a member of the editorial board of Americas Quarterly, a policy publication focused on relations and development in the Western Hemisphere.
In May 2007, Brown University announced that Lagos would take a teaching position at the Watson Institute for International Studies for a period of five years, starting on 1 July 2007.
In May 2007, Brown University announced that Lagos would take a teaching position at the Watson Institute for International Studies for a period of five years, starting on 1 July 2007.
In 2013, Lagos was a visiting professor at the University of São Paulo assuming the 'José Bonifácio Cátedra'.
On 24 May 2018, he was awarded the Doctor of Laws degree by Harvard University.

roles.title: professor
